page.title: List of churches, chapels and meeting halls in the Channel Islands

revision.text:
This is a '''list of churches, chapels and meeting halls in the Channel Islands'''
==First millennium== [[Image:Hermitage St Helier Jersey.jpg|thumb|right|130px|The Hermitage of [[Saint Helier]]]] Although there are indications that missionary efforts created small places of Christian worship in various places in the islands before 450 A.D.<ref name="CIC">{{cite book |last=McCormack |first=John |title=Channel Island Churches |publisher=Phillimore & Co Ltd 1886 |ISBN=0850335418}}</ref>{{rp|29}} the first proper evidence of Christianity is recorded as coming to the Islands around 520 A.D. when [[Samson of Dol]] visited [[Guernsey]] and in 540 A.D. when [[Helier]] arrived in [[Jersey]], living as a hermit until he was killed by pirates.<ref name=JD41/>{{rp|65}}
The "pirates" grew in strength. In 911 A.D., a group of "pirates", or [[Vikings]] led by [[Rollo]] besieged [[Paris]] and [[Chartres]]. After a victory near Chartres on 26 August, [[Charles the Simple]] decided to negotiate with Rollo, resulting in the [[Treaty of Saint-Clair-sur-Epte]]. For the Vikings' loyalty, they were granted all the land between the river [[Epte]] and the sea, as well as [[Brittany]], which at the time was an independent country which France had unsuccessfully tried to conquer. Rollo also agreed to be baptised and to marry Charles' daughter, [[Gisela of France|Gisela]]. The land would become known as "Normandy", the land of the North Men and included "Les Îles d'la Manche" or the Channel Islands. Religion was strengthened with the arrival and conversion of the [[Normans]] to Christianity, in the 10th Century.<ref name=JerCom/>
==Second millennium==
There were many churches built by the Normans in the 11th and 12th centuries, many on top of previous chapels which were themselves alongside pagan places of worship,<ref name=CIC/>{{rp|53–55}} the islands being divided up into parishes in the 11th Century and land areas granted by endowment to French-based religious centres, [[Mont Saint Michel Abbey]] received four and [[Marmoutier Abbey, Tours]] six from Guernsey, [[Cerisy-la-Forêt]] acquired two in Jersey, but most other Jersey parishes were scattered amongst other people and institutions.<ref name=CIC/>{{rp|53}}
The Islands embraced the French Calvinist form of [[Protestantism]] during the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]] [[Catholic Church in Jersey|Roman Catholicism]] continued until orders were received to remove all signs of Catholicism in 1547. A brief return to Catholicism saw the three women turned into [[Guernsey Martyrs|martyrs]] before another turn, back to the Protestant faith and a fear of France and Catholics.<ref name="Black">{{cite book |first=Henry |last=Wimbush |title=The Channel islands |publisher=AC Black 1924}}</ref>{{rp|95}} Methodism took a stronghold at the end of the 18th Century.<ref name="JerCom">{{cite web |url=https://www.jersey.com/english/sightsandactivities/walking/routes/Pages/default.aspx?itemid=27eb2436-18ab-4a9a-8ed6-cb096ca3ae5a&start=1 |title=Religion in Jersey |publisher=Jersey.com}}</ref> [[Image:Little Chapel op Guernsey.JPG|thumb|150px| Little Chapel, Guernsey]] The [[Little Chapel]] in [[Guernsey]] has been said that it "is the smallest functioning chapel in Europe, if not the world", and<ref name="RL">{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/travel/article-2061853/Guernsey-holidays-Rula-Lenska-finds-Channel-Islands-world-away.html | title=An actress calls: Rula Lenska hops over to Guernsey but finds it a world away | work=Mail Online | date=15 November 2011 | accessdate=30 June 2013 | author=Lenska, Rula}}</ref><ref name="Mail Online">{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/travel/article-610080/A-royal-family-affair-Guernsey.html | title=A royal family affair on Guernsey | work=Mail Online | date=2 July 2008 | accessdate=30 June 2013 | author=Bond, Jennie}}</ref> it is "believed to be the world’s smallest [[consecrated]] church."<ref name="Express">{{cite web | url=http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/travel/348925/Warm-to-a-taste-of-the-Gallic-in-Guernsey | title=Warm to a taste of the Gallic in Guernsey | work=Express | date=29 September 2012 | accessdate=30 June 2013 | author=Kelly, Fergus}}</ref><ref name="Size">{{cite web | url=http://www.premierholidays.co.uk/channel_islands_and_the_isle_of_man/guernsey/guernsey_destination_guide | title=Guernsey Destination Guide | publisher=Premier Holidays | accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref>
At least three churches in Guernsey have pre history carved stones, the most famous being La Gran'mère du Chimquière.<ref name="MGGM">{{cite web |url=http://www.megalithicguernsey.co.uk/la-granmere-du-chimquiere/ |title=La Gran’mère du Chimquière |publisher=Megalithic Guernsey}}</ref> In Jersey, at [[La Hougue Bie]] a 12th Century chapel was built on a [[Neolithic]] ritual site which was in use around 3500 BC. In [[Western Europe]], it is one of the largest and best preserved [[passage graves]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Statements in Stone: Monuments and Society in Neolithic Europe|author= Mark Patton|year= 1993|publisher=Routledge (UK)|url=https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0415067294&id=169_3pCX9EUC&pg=PA96&lpg=PA96&ots=b-yvovCtRv&dq=%22La+Hougue+Bie%22&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html&sig=Y9S5BAodEkc7S_J6iCqQxotYSng|isbn=0415067294}}</ref> Several churches, including Castel Church, Guernsey, have been built using materials dating back to the [[Roman Empire]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.twcenter.net/forums/showthread.php?346611-Guernsey-the-Roman-Empire-s-trading-post |title=Guernsey the Roman Empire's trading post |publisher=Total War Centre}}</ref> St Saviour Church in Guernsey has a number of tunnels running underneath, built by the [[Organisation Todt]] for [[Nazi Germany]] in the 1940s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-09-10/news/mn-2588_1_guernsey-women |title=Wartime Nazi Tunnels on Guernsey Posing Problem |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=10 September 1989}}</ref>
The historic toleration of religious minorities has led to many persecuted minorities seeking refuge in the Islands, such as Huguenots from 1548.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.genealogyforum.com/gfaol/resource/Huguenot/hug0006.htm |title=HUGUENOT & PROTESTANT REFORMED CHRONOLOGY |publisher=genealogyforum}}</ref> The influx of the Protestant refugees led to [[Calvinism]] becoming the main religion, forcing a break from the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Coutances]] in 1568 to the [[Bishop of Winchester]]. Religion became strictly enforced with physical punishments (whippings, stocks, imprisonment) and torture to get confessions for [[Channel Islands Witch Trials]] for 100 years, ending only with the [[Act of Uniformity 1662]] of [[Charles II of England]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Girard |first=Peter |title=More of Peter Girard's Guernsey: A Second Miscellany of Guernsey's History and Its People |publisher=Guernsey Press |ISBN=978-0902550421 |date=1990}}</ref>{{rp|153}} In the [[Channel Islands in the Wars of the Three Kingdoms|English Civil War]] Guernsey, with stronger puritanical sympathies supported Parliament whereas Jersey was happy to restore episcopalian constitutions, siding with the Royalists.<ref>{{cite book |first=S. Elliott |last=Hoskins |title=Charles the Second in the Channel Islands |publisher=Richard Bentley 1854}}</ref>
A famous refugee Guernsey in 1855 was [[Victor Hugo]] who increasingly expressed anti-Catholic and [[anti-clerical]] views. Hugo counted 740 attacks on a book he wrote whilst in Guernsey, ''[[Les Misérables]]'' in the Catholic press.<ref>{{cite book|last=Robb|first=Graham|title=Victor Hugo|year=1997|publisher=Picador|location=London|pages=32|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kU9LloPylhQC&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32}}</ref> The last major act of non-toleration goes back to 1556, with the [[Guernsey Martyrs]] who died for their Protestant faith. The Island's toleration has left a rich legacy of churches, chapels and places of worship.
The maintenance of Parish churches was, before the Reformation, the responsibility of the Catholic church. To avoid the English Crown taking over responsibility as successor, [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] in 1677 instructed the Guernsey churchwardens to raise monies from the parishioners.<ref>{{cite book |first=Darryl |last=Ogier |title=The Government and Law of Guernsey |publisher= States of Guernsey |ISBN=978-0-9549775-1-1}}</ref>
In 1893 a religious census was undertaken in Guernsey showing around 50% of the population attended:<ref name="Crossan">{{cite book |last=Crossan |first=Rose-Marie |title=Guernsey 1814-1914: Migration and Modernisation |publisher=Boydell Press |ISBN=978-1843833208}}</ref>{{rp|194}} {{col-start}} {{col-2}} * Anglican - 17 places - 5,998 attendants * French Wesleyan - 17 places - 2,989 attendants * Salvation Army - 4 places - 1,941 attendants * English Wesleyan - 6 places - 1,783 attendants * English R.C. - 2 places - 1,021 attendants * Baptist - 6 places - 663 attendants {{col-2}} * French R.C. - 2 places - 588 attendants * Independent - 5 places - 533 attendants * Brethren - 6 places - 507 attendants * New Connexion - 1 place - 452 attendants * Primitive Methodist - 2 places - 315 attendants * Other - 7 places - 800 attendants {{col-end}}
2010 breakdown of followers in the [[Channel Islands]]:<ref>{{cite book |title= Religions of the World: A Comprehensive Encyclopedia of Beliefs and Practices |ISBN= 9781598842043 |page=538 }}</ref> {{col-start}} {{col-4}} * Christians 84% {{col-4}} * [[Agnosticism|Agnostics]] 14% {{col-4}} * Atheists 1% {{col-4}} * Other religions 1% {{col-end}}
==Religions==
* [[Anglicanism]] - The [[Deanery of Guernsey]] of the Church of England comes under the [[Diocese of Canterbury]], but until 2015 was under the [[Diocese of Winchester]]. * [[Baptists]] - The Baptist Christian faith has been practiced in Guernsey for over 200 years.<ref>{{cite book |first=Tim |last=Grass |title=Two centuries of Baptists in Guernsey |ISBN= 978-0957319028}}</ref> * [[Church of Scotland]] - The Church has very few churches outside Scotland, but both Guernsey and Jersey have Kirks. They were established, partly to cater for the Scottish soldiers who regularly provided garrison duties. * [[Elim Pentecostal Church]] - For over 100 years there has been a Pentecostal Church in the Islands, with Elim expanding in the 1930s. * [[Evangelicalism]] – Auxiliary Associations existed in Gernsey and Jersey in 1814 <ref>{{cite book |title=Evangelical Magazine and Missionary Chronicle |issue=Volume 22 1814}}</ref> * Greater World Christian Spiritualism – held its first service in Jersey in 1935. * [[Islam]] There are no mosques or meeting places in [[Islam in Guernsey|Guernsey]], Jersey has a meeting house.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/jersey/content/articles/2005/03/02/islam_in_jersey_3_feature.shtml |title= ISLAM IN JERSEY |publisher=BBC |date=24 September 2014}}</ref> * [[Judaism]] - Jews first established a synagogue in [[Saint Helier]] in 1843.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jewishgen.org/jcr-uk/community/jersey/jewishpress1843-1936.htm |title= Press Reports relating to the Jersey Jewish Community 1843 to 1936 |publisher=JCR UK}}</ref> * [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] – Two English congregations and one Portuguese group in Guernsey. Three English congregations and one Portuguese congregation in Jersey. * [[Methodism]] - Methodism reached Jersey in 1774.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.methodistheritage.org.uk/jerseyandguernesy.htm |title=Jersey & Guernesy |publisher=Methodist Heritage}}</ref> The first Methodist minister in Jersey was appointed in 1783, and [[John Wesley]] preached in Guernsey in 1787 and in Jersey in August 1789. The first Wesleyan chapel was built in Guernsey in 1788 opposite the Royal Court. Channel Islands District of the Methodist Church <ref name="JD41">{{cite book |first=Jonathan |last=Duncan |title=The History of Guernsey: With Occasional Notices of Jersey, Alderney, and Sark, and Biographical Sketches |publisher=Longman, Brown, Green, and Longmans, 1841}}</ref>{{rp|356}} * [[Newfrontiers]] – A network of evangelical charismatic churches. Represented in Guernsey * Portuguese Christian Mission – Established in Jersey in 2009 to cater for the Portuguese community * [[Quakers]] - The Religious Society of Friends believed to have been active in Jersey around 1660.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hampshirequakers.org.uk/jerseyhistory.php#1660s |title=The 1660s in Southampton and Jersey |publisher=Hampshire Quakers}}</ref> Recognised in the Island in 1742. In Guernsey they formed a society in 1782. * [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] - The Catholic diocese comes under the jurisdiction of the English [[Catholic Diocese of Portsmouth|Diocese of Portsmouth]]. * [[The Salvation Army|Salvation Army]] - Founded in Jersey in 1879 and in Guernsey in 1881 and in Alderney in 1882. The Army's founders, Catherine and [[William Booth]], had visited Guernsey in 1855 shortly after their marriage and preached. Marie Ozanne died for her beliefs in Guernsey in 1943.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-guernsey-21557669 |title=Guernsey WWII heroine Marie Ozanne blue plaque unveiled |publisher=BBC |date=23 February 2013}}</ref> * [[United Reformed Church]] was formed in 1972 when the Presbyterian Church of England and the Congregational Church of England came together. Presbyterian churches have served the Islands for over 100 years.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.guernseygazette.com/v2_news_articles.php?heading=0&page=72&story_id=774 |title= Local Presbyterian Church to celebrate 100 yearsí service |date=18 May 2010}}</ref> * Zion Christian Fellowship – Founded in Guernsey in 1988.

page.title: List of dialling codes in Brazil

revision.comment: The previous image had unaccurate data, replaced with a image with accurate data
revision.text:
'''[[Country calling code|Country Code]]: +55'''
'''[[International Call Prefix]]: 00 then Carrier Code'''
'''[[Trunk Prefix]]: 0 then Carrier Code''' This page contains a list of '''[[area code]]s in [[Brazil]]''' for telephone dialing. The area codes are distributed geographically, citing the main cities in each area. Local phone numbers in Brazil observe an eight-digit pattern (''nnnn-nnnn'') for [[landline]]s and nine digits (''nnnnn-nnnn'') for [[mobile phone]]s. Mobile numbers share the same geographic area codes as landlines, but the first digit differentiates them. Landline numbers start with digits ''2'' through ''5''. Initial digits ''6'' through ''9'' are reserved for mobile numbers, but as of 2017 all mobile numbers in Brazil start with the digit ''9''. (There is an exception for some [[iDEN]] mobile lines operated by [[NII Holdings|Nextel]], which are eight digits long and start with ''7''.) Area codes have two digits, and are often notated between parentheses: ''(aa) nnnn-nnnn''. For [[long-distance call]]s '''within''' Brazil, a zero (''0'') must be dialed first, then a carrier selection code (for example, ''21'' for [[Embratel]] and ''41'' for [[TIM Brasil]]), then the two-digit area code, then the local number. For example, to call the number ''2222-2222'' in [[Fortaleza]] (area code ''85'') using [[Oi (telecommunications)|Oi]] (selection code ''31'') as the chosen carrier, one would dial '''0 31 85 2222 2222'''. For [[international call]]s '''to''' Brazil, the international access code used in the calling country must be dialed (for example, ''011'' from the [[United States]] and [[Canada]], ''00'' from [[Europe]] and most other countries, or the actual "+" sign from some mobile networks), then Brazil's country code '''55''', then the two-digit area code, then the local eight- or nine-digit number. For example, to call the number ''3333-3333'' in [[Rio de Janeiro]] (area code ''21'') from Europe, one would dial '''00 55 21 3333 3333'''. [[File:Brasil - Códigos de área DDD.png|alt=|thumb|300x300px|Map of Brazilian area code ranges by state]] ==''1'' State of [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo]]== *11 - [[Greater São Paulo|São Paulo]] metropolitan area *12 - [[Vale do Paraíba]] ([[São José dos Campos]], [[Taubaté]], [[Guaratinguetá]]) and Northern coast ([[Ubatuba]], [[São Sebastião, São Paulo|São Sebastião]]) *13 - [[Baixada Santista]] ([[Santos, São Paulo|Santos]], [[São Vicente, São Paulo|São Vicente]], [[Guarujá]]) and Southern coast ([[Registro]], [[Itanhaém]]) *14 - Central ([[Bauru]], [[Marília]], [[Botucatu]]) *15 - Southwest ([[Sorocaba]], [[Itapetininga]]) *16 - Northeast ([[Ribeirão Preto]], [[Franca]], [[São Carlos]]) *17 - Northwest ([[São José do Rio Preto]], [[Catanduva]]) *18 - West ([[Presidente Prudente, São Paulo|Presidente Prudente]], [[Araçatuba]]) *19 - Central-South ([[Campinas]], [[Piracicaba]], [[Limeira]]) ==''2'' States of [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]] and [[Espírito Santo]]== ===[[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]] (21, 22 and 24)=== *21 - Greater [[Rio de Janeiro]] and [[Teresópolis]] *22 - East and North ([[Campos dos Goytacazes]], [[Cabo Frio]], [[Nova Friburgo]]) *23 - reserved *24 - West ([[Petrópolis]], [[Volta Redonda]], [[Angra dos Reis]]) *25 and 26 - reserved ===[[Espírito Santo]] (27 and 28)=== *27 - Central and North ([[Vitória, Espírito Santo|Vitória]], [[Linhares]], [[Colatina]]) *28 - South ([[Cachoeiro de Itapemirim]]) *29 - reserved ==''3'' State of [[Minas Gerais]]== *31 - Central (Greater [[Belo Horizonte]], [[Sete Lagoas]], [[Ipatinga]]) *32 - Southeast ([[Juiz de Fora]], [[Muriaé]], [[Barbacena]]) *33 - East and Northeast ([[Governador Valadares]], [[Teófilo Otoni]]) *34 - West ([[Uberlândia]], [[Uberaba]], [[Patos de Minas]]) *35 - Southwest ([[Poços de Caldas]], [[Varginha]], [[Pouso Alegre]]) *36 - reserved *37 - Central-West ([[Divinópolis]]) *38 - North ([[Montes Claros]], [[Diamantina, Minas Gerais|Diamantina]]) *39 - reserved ==''4'' States of [[Paraná (state)|Paraná]] and [[Santa Catarina (state)|Santa Catarina]]== ===[[Paraná (state)|Paraná]] (41 to 46)=== *41 - Greater [[Curitiba]] and coast ([[Paranaguá]]) *42 - Central-South ([[Ponta Grossa]], [[Guarapuava]]) *43 - Northeast ([[Londrina]], [[Apucarana]]) *44 - Northwest ([[Maringá]], [[Umuarama]]) *45 - West ([[Foz do Iguaçu]], [[Cascavel]]) *46 - Southwest ([[Francisco Beltrão]], [[Pato Branco]]) ===[[Santa Catarina (state)|Santa Catarina]] (47 to 49)=== *47 - Northeast ([[Joinville]], [[Blumenau]], [[Itajaí]]) *48 - Greater [[Florianópolis]] and South ([[Criciúma]], [[Tubarão]]) *49 - Central and West ([[Lages]], [[Chapecó]]) ==''5'' State of [[Rio Grande do Sul]]== *51 - Greater [[Porto Alegre]], Central-South ([[Santa Cruz do Sul]]), Northern coast ([[Torres, Rio Grande do Sul|Torres]]) *52 - reserved *53 - South ([[Pelotas]], [[Rio Grande]], [[Bagé]]) *54 - North ([[Caxias do Sul]], [[Passo Fundo]]) *55 - Central, West and Northwest ([[Santa Maria, Rio Grande do Sul|Santa Maria]], [[Uruguaiana]], [[Ijuí]]) *56 to 59 - reserved ==''6'' Central-West Region and states of [[Tocantins (state)|Tocantins]], [[Acre (state)|Acre]] and [[Rondônia]]== ===[[Federal District (Brazil)|Federal District]] (part of 61)=== *61 - entire Federal District ([[Brasília]]) and [[Entorno do Distrito Federal Microregion|surrounding area of Goiás state]] ===[[Goiás]] (part of 61, plus 62 and 64)=== *61 - [[Entorno do Distrito Federal Microregion|area surrounding Brasília]] *62 - Central and North (Greater [[Goiânia]], [[Anápolis]]) *64 - South and West ([[Rio Verde, Goiás|Rio Verde]], [[Itumbiara]], [[Catalão]]) ===[[Tocantins (state)|Tocantins]] (63)=== *63 - entire State of Tocantins (capital city [[Palmas, Tocantins|Palmas]]) ===[[Mato Grosso]] (65 and 66)=== *65 - Southwest ([[Cuiabá]], [[Cáceres, Mato Grosso|Cáceres]]) *66 - East and North ([[Rondonópolis]], [[Sinop, Mato Grosso|Sinop]]) ===[[Mato Grosso do Sul]] (67)=== *67 - entire State of Mato Grosso do Sul (capital city [[Campo Grande]]) ===[[Acre (state)|Acre]] (68)=== *68 - entire State of Acre (capital city [[Rio Branco, Acre|Rio Branco]]) ===[[Rondônia]] (69)=== *69 - entire State of Rondônia (capital city [[Porto Velho]]) ==''7'' States of [[Bahia]] and [[Sergipe]]== ===[[Bahia]] (71, 73-75, 77)=== *71 - Greater [[Salvador, Bahia|Salvador]] *72 - reserved *73 - South ([[Ilhéus]], [[Itabuna]], [[Porto Seguro]], [[Jequié]]) *74 - Northwest ([[Juazeiro]]) *75 - Northeast ([[Feira de Santana]]) *76 - reserved *77 - Southwest and West ([[Vitória da Conquista]], [[Barreiras]]) *78 - reserved (formerly used by [[Embratel]] for maritime telecommunications and for the RENPAC dialled data communication system) ===[[Sergipe]] (79)=== *79 - entire State of Sergipe (capital city [[Aracaju]]) ==''8'' Northeast Region== ===[[Pernambuco]] (81 and 87)=== *81 - East (Greater [[Recife]], [[Caruaru]], [[Fernando de Noronha]]) *87 - Central and West ([[Petrolina]], [[Garanhuns]]) ===[[Alagoas]] (82)=== *82 - entire State of Alagoas (capital city [[Maceió]]) ===[[Paraíba]] (83)=== *83 - entire State of Paraíba (capital city [[João Pessoa, Paraíba|João Pessoa]]) ===[[Rio Grande do Norte]] (84)=== *84 - entire State of Rio Grande do Norte (capital city [[Natal, Rio Grande do Norte|Natal]]) ===[[Ceará]] (85 and 88)=== *85 - Greater [[Fortaleza]] *88 - Central, West and South ([[Juazeiro do Norte]], [[Sobral, Ceará|Sobral]]) ===[[Piauí]] (86 and 89)=== *86 - North ([[Teresina]], [[Parnaíba]]) *89 - Central and South ([[Picos]], [[Floriano, Piauí|Floriano]]) ==''9'' North Region and the state of Maranhão== ===[[Pará]] (91, 93 and 94)=== *91 - Northeast (Greater [[Belém]], [[Capanema, Pará|Capanema]]) *93 - Central and West ([[Santarém, Pará|Santarém]], [[Altamira, Pará|Altamira]]) *94 - Southeast ([[Marabá]], [[Carajás Mine|Carajás]]) ===[[Amazonas State, Brazil|Amazonas]] (92 and 97)=== *92 - Northeast (Greater [[Manaus]], [[Itacoatiara, Amazonas|Itacoatiara]], [[Parintins]]) *97 - Central, South and West ([[Coari]], [[Tabatinga]], [[Humaitá, Amazonas|Humaitá]]) ===[[Roraima]] (95)=== *95 - entire State of Roraima (capital city [[Boa Vista, Roraima|Boa Vista]]) ===[[Amapá]] (96)=== *96 - entire State of Amapá (capital city [[Macapá]]) ===[[Maranhão]] (98 and 99)=== *98 - North (Greater [[São Luís, Maranhão|São Luís]], [[Pinheiro, Maranhão|Pinheiro]]) *99 - Central and South ([[Imperatriz]], [[Caxias, Maranhão|Caxias]]) ==Exceptions== In a few exceptional cases, some area codes span state borders to cater for tightly integrated interstate communities: *The village of Maringá (not to be confused with the [[Maringá|homonymous large city]] in the State of [[Paraná (state)|Paraná]]) straddles the [[Minas Gerais]]-[[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]] border, and both sides use the Rio de Janeiro area code '''24'''. The rest of the municipality of [[Bocaina de Minas]], where the Minas Gerais part of the village is located, uses the proper regional area code '''32'''. *Two border cities in the State of [[Paraná (state)|Paraná]] are contiguous with larger cities in [[Santa Catarina (state)|Santa Catarina]] and use area codes from the latter state: [[Rio Negro, Paraná|Rio Negro]] (contiguous with [[Mafra, Santa Catarina|Mafra]]) uses area code '''47''', and [[Barracão, Paraná|Barracão]] (contiguous with [[Dionísio Cerqueira]]) uses area code '''49'''. *Conversely, the border city of [[Porto União]] in the State of [[Santa Catarina (state)|Santa Catarina]] is contiguous with the larger [[Paraná (state)|Paraná]] city of [[União da Vitória]] and uses the latter state's area code '''42'''. *Area code '''61''' primarily serves the [[Federal District (Brazil)|Federal District]] (comprising the national capital city, [[Brasília]]), but it also serves some surrounding municipalities in the State of [[Goiás]], such as [[Formosa, Goiás|Formosa]], [[Valparaíso de Goiás]] and [[Luziânia]]. Formerly, area code 61 was even larger and used to include northwestern [[Minas Gerais]] ([[Unaí]], [[Paracatu, Minas Gerais|Paracatu]]), now in that state's area code '''38'''. *The city of [[Alto Parnaíba]], in the State of [[Maranhão]], is conurbated with [[Santa Filomena, Piauí|Santa Filomena]], State of [[Piauí]], and uses the latter state's area code '''89''' for landlines. Most local mobile phones, though, use Southern Maranhão area code '''99'''. ==See also== *[[Telephone numbers in Brazil]] *[[List of postal codes in Brazil]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.itu.int/oth/T020200001D/en ITU allocations list] ==External links== *[http://www.codigosddd.com.br/ List of all area codes (DDD codes) in Brazil] {{South America topic|Telephone numbers in}} [[Category:Telephone numbers by country|Brazil]] [[Category:Telephone numbers in Brazil| ]]

page.title: List of extreme points of Romania

revision.comment: correct diacritics, replaced: Cernăuţi → Cernăuți using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
This is a list of the '''extreme points of [[Romania]]''', the points that are farther [[north]], [[south]], [[east]] or [[west]] than any other location.
==Latitude and longitude== *Northernmost point: [[Păltiniș, Botoșani|Horodiștea]], a village in [[Botoșani County]], on the border with [[Ukraine]], {{coord|48|15|N|26|43|E|type:landmark_region:RO|name=Horodiștea (North)}} **''Historical: [[Babin, Zastavna|Babin]], [[Cernăuți County]] (now Babin, [[Chernivtsi Oblast]], Ukraine)'' *Southernmost point: [[Zimnicea]], a town in [[Teleorman County]], on the border with [[Bulgaria]], {{coord|43|40|N|25|22|E|type:landmark_region:RO|name=Zimnicea (South)}} **''Historical: [[Ecrene]], [[Caliacra County]] (now Kranevo, [[Dobrich Province]], Bulgaria)'' *Westernmost point: [[Beba Veche]], a village in [[Timiș County]], on the border with [[Hungary]] and [[Serbia]], {{coord|46|08|N|20|19|E|type:landmark_region:RO|name=Beba Veche (West)}} *Easternmost point: [[Sulina]], a town in [[Tulcea County]], on the [[Danube Delta]], {{coord|45|09|N|29|40|E|type:landmark_region:RO|name=Sulina (East)}}. Also the easternmost point in the contiguous EU (21 states). **''Historical: [[Bugaz]], [[Cetatea Albă County]] (now Zatoka, Odessa Oblast, Ukraine)''
==Height== * Highest Point: [[Moldoveanu Peak]], in the [[Făgăraș Mountains]], (2,544 m), {{coord|45|35|57|N|24|44|10|E|type:mountain_region:RO|name=Moldoveanu Peak (highest)}} * Lowest Point: [[Black Sea]] shore
== See also ==
* [[Geography of Romania]] * [[Extreme points of Europe]] * [[Extreme points of the European Union]]
{{Extreme points of Europe}}
[[Category:Geography of Romania]] [[Category:Lists of coordinates]] [[Category:Extreme points by country|Romania]] [[Category:Lists of landforms of Romania|Extreme]]
