page.title: List of non-marine molluscs of the Gambier Islands

revision.text:
The '''non-marine molluscs of the [[Gambier Islands]]''' are a part of the molluscan [[fauna]] of [[French Polynesia]].
==Introduction== There are ___ {{clarification needed|date=October 2014}} species of [[Mollusca|molluscs]] living in the wild in the Gambier Islands area. There are a total of ___ species of [[Gastropoda|gastropods]], which breaks down to ___ species of [[freshwater gastropod]]s, and ___ species of land gastropods in ___ genera, plus ___ species of [[Bivalvia|bivalves]] living in the wild.
There is a high degree of [[endemic|endemism]] of these species. The gastropod fauna has been affected by severe alterations to the [[natural environment]] of the Gambier Islands.<ref name="Bouchet 2001"/>
== Land gastropods == *[[Assimineidae]] ::* † ''[[Cyclomorpha secessa]]'' Bouchet & Abdou, 2003 - endemic<ref name="Bouchet 2003">Bouchet P. & Abdou A. (2003). "Endemic land snails from the Pacific islands and the museum record: documenting and dating the extinction of the terrestrial Assimineidae of the Gambier Islands". ''[[Journal of Molluscan Studies]]'' '''69'''(3): 165-170. {{doi|10.1093/mollus/69.3.165}}.</ref> ::* † ''[[Omphalotropis margarita]]'' (Pfeiffer, 1851) - endemic<ref name="Bouchet 2003"/>
*[[Euconulidae]] ::* † ''[[Aukena endodonta]]'' Bouchet & Abdou, 2001 - endemic<ref name="Bouchet 2001">Bouchet P. & Abdou A. (2001). "Recent Extinct Land Snails (Euconulidae) from the Gambier Islands with Remarkable Apertural Barriers". ''[[Pacific Science]]'' '''55'''(2): 121-127. {{doi|10.1353/psc.2001.0011}}.</ref> ::* † ''[[Aukena tridentata]]'' (Baker, 1940) - endemic<ref name="Bouchet 2001"/> ::* ''[[Philonesia mangarevae]]'' Baker, 1940 - endemic, at the base of [[Mount Mokoto]]<ref name="Bouchet 2001"/>
{{Expand section|date=April 2011}}
==Freshwater bivalvia== The status of non-marine [[bivalve]]s in this area is currently unknown.
==See also== * [[List of non-marine molluscs of the Pitcairn Islands]] * [[List of non-marine molluscs of the Cook Islands]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
{{DEFAULTSORT:Molluscs Gambier Islands}} [[Category:Fauna of French Polynesia|*Molluscs]] [[Category:Gambier Islands|List]] [[Category:Molluscs of Oceania|*Gambier]] [[Category:Lists of molluscs by country|Gambier Islands]] [[Category:French Polynesia-related lists|Molluscs]]

page.title: Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles

revision.comment: Interesting [user:PamD]; i have attached two refs for the moment (TheMountainGuide is also I think a download of DoBIH and I would suspect from the sime time I downloaded; Peakbagger lists two peaks at 119, one being MB at 600m). Hoever, DoBIH is the best source, and perhaps have decided to downgrade MB back to sub 600. Let me try and chase this up with DoBIH to see what it happening. The problem with prominences !
revision.text:
{{short description|Highest mountains in the British Isles}}
{{see also|List of mountains of the British Isles by height}}
The '''mountains and hills of the British Isles''', are categorised into '''lists''' based on [[elevation]] (or "height"), [[topographic prominence|prominence]] (or "relative height", or "drop"), and other criteria (e.g. [[topographic isolation|isolation]]). These lists are used for [[peak bagging]], whereby [[hillwalking|hillwalkers]] attempt to reach all the summits on a list, the oldest and best-known, being the 282 {{slink|#Munros}} in Scotland, which amongst other criteria, must be above {{convert|3000|ft|1}}.
[[File:Scafell massif.jpg|thumb|upright=1.8|[[Scafell Pike]] in the [[Lake District]] in [[Cumbria]]. Scafell Pike is the highest mountain in [[England]], and the 257th highest mountain in the British Isles on the Simms classification, the 138th highest mountain on the Marilyn classification, and the 46th highest mountain on the P600 classification. Scafell Pike has the 13th greatest "relative height" (or prominence) in the British Isles. It is also classed as a Marilyn, a HuMP, a Furth, a Hewitt, a Nuttall, a Wainright, a Birkett, and a County Top.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/mountaindetails.php?qu=CoU&rf=2359|title=Scafell Pike|publisher=HillBagging|access-date=8 November 2018}}</ref>]]
A height above 2,000 ft, or more latterly 600 m, is considered necessary to be a "mountain" in the British Isles, and apart from the Munros (who favour isolation), all lists require a prominence of at least {{convert|15|m|sigfig=4}}. A prominence of between {{convert|15-30|m|sigfig=4}} (e.g. some {{slink|#Nuttalls}} and {{slink|#Vandeleur-Lynams}}), does not meet the [[UIAA]] definition of an "independent" [[summit|peak]]. Most lists consider a prominence between {{convert|30-150|m|sigfig=4}} as a "top", and not a mountain (e.g. many {{slink|#Hewitts}} and {{slink|#Simms}}). A popular designation are the {{slink|#Marilyns}}, with a prominence above {{convert|150|m|sigfig=4}}. Prominences above {{convert|600|m|sigfig=4}}, are the {{slink|#P600 (the "Majors")}}, the international classification of a "major" mountain.
==General concepts==
===Elevation===
There is no worldwide consensus on the definition of "mountain", but in Great Britain and Ireland it is often taken to be any summit at least 2,000 feet (or 610 metres) high (also called [[elevation]]).<ref name="Nuttall 2008">{{cite book | last=Nuttall | first=John & Anne | title=The Mountains of England & Wales – Volume 2: England | edition=3rd | year=2008 | publisher=Cicerone | location=Milnthorpe, Cumbria | isbn=1-85284-037-4}}</ref><ref>[http://2/hi/uk_news/wales/north_west/7623904.stm ''Survey turns hill into a mountain'']{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} at news.bbc.co.uk. Accessed on 3 Feb 2013.</ref><ref name="G4AW">[http://www.go4awalk.com/uk-mountains-and-hills/a-mountain-is-a-mountain.php ''A Mountain is a Mountain – isn't it?''] at www.go4awalk.com. Accessed on 3 Feb 2013.</ref><ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com///browse/mountain ''mountain''] at dictionary.reference.com. Accessed on 3 Feb 2013.</ref><ref>Wilson, Peter (2001). ''Listing the Irish hills and mountains'' in ''Irish Geography'', Vol 34(1), University of Ulster, Coleraine, p. 89. [http://www.ucd.ie/gsi/pdf/34-1/hills.pdf] (pdf)</ref> The UK government defines ''mountain'' as land over {{convert|600|m|sigfig=4}} for the purposes of freedom of access.<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2000/37/pdfs/ukpga_20000037_en.pdf ''Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000''], Part 1, Chapter 1, Section 1(2). Accessed on 14 Feb 2013.</ref> When [[Calf Top]] in [[Cumbria]], was re-surveyed 2016 and confirmed to be almost exactly 2,000 ft, 6 millimetres above the 609.6 m threshold for a 2,000 ft peak, the [[Ordnance Survey]] described Calf Top as England's "last mountain".<ref name="calf">{{cite web|url=https://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/blog/2016/09/calf-top-englands-last-mountain/?awc=2495_1473771290_461b077cbec61db38509cb4f9ed3f27c|title=Calf Top: England's last mountain|date=8 September 2016|publisher=[[Ordnance Survey]]|quote=In all probability Calf Top will be the last such hill to become a mountain in England.}}</ref>
* [[List of mountains of the British Isles by height]], a ranking by height and prominence on the Simms classification (height over 600m, prominence over 30 m) * [[List of Marilyns in the British Isles]], a ranking by height and prominence on the Marilyn classification (any height, prominence over 150 m) * [[List of P600 mountains in the British Isles]], a ranking by height and prominence on the P600 classification (any height, prominence over 600 m)
===Prominence===
In addition, all British Isles definitions, with the exception of definitions that rely on {{slink|#Isolation}}, include a minimum [[topographical prominence]] requirement (also called relative height, or drop, or re-ascent, between neighbouring peaks), which is typically {{convert|30-600|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name="G4AW"/> The lowest minimum prominence is {{convert|15|m|sigfig=4}}, the Nuttalls and Vandeleur-Lynams, however most definitions do not consider prominences below {{convert|30|m|sigfig=4}}. Many definitions use the term '''Tops''' to refer to the sub-class of peaks that do not meet a {{convert|150|m|sigfig=4}} prominence threshold for the main definition, but have a prominence of between {{convert|30-150|m|sigfig=4}}. Some definitions ignore height completely and just focus purely on prominence (e.g. P600s, Marilyns, and HuMPs).
Prominence requirements are even strongly debated regarding [[UIAA]] classification of major Himalayan mountains.<ref name="bbc1">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-24571309|title=Nepal mountain peak expansion bid stalls|publisher=BBC News|date=18 October 2013|quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.markhorrell.com/blog/2014/a-funny-name-for-a-mountain/|title=A funny name for a mountain|publisher=Mark Horrell|date=4 June 2014|quote=I explained how these five ridgetops couldn’t possibly be classified as 8000m peaks in their own right because each of them requires less than 135 metres of re-ascent between their respective parent peaks, Kangchenjunga and Lhotse (known as topographic prominence). It seems that where logic and common sense fail the NMA feels that flattery may work instead. }}</ref> In 1994, regarding classification of [[summit]]s, the UIAA stated that for a "peak" to be independent (e.g. not a sub-peak of a mountain), it needed a prominence over 30 m, and in addition, a "mountain" had to have a prominence over 300 m.<ref name="uiaa">{{cite web|url=https://www.theuiaa.org/mountaineering/mountain-classification/|title=MOUNTAIN CLASSIFICATION|publisher=[[UIAA]]|date=March 1994|quote=Topographic criterium: for each summit, the level difference between it and the highest adjacent pass or notch should be at least 30 m (calculated as average of the summits at the limit of acceptability).}}</ref>
Unlike the single measurement of elevation, prominence requires the detailed measurement of all contours around the peak, and is therefore subject to change and revision over time, and thus tables based on prominence are subject to revision.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rhb.org.uk/marhofn/marhofn316/marhofn31618.htm|date=March 2016|title=Surveying and mapping standards|author=Alan Dawson|publisher=The Relative Hills of Britain (rhb.org.uk)}}</ref> Some definitions use an [[imperial measurement]] for height, but a metric measurement for the topological prominence (e.g. Murdos, Hewitts and Nuttals).
* [[List of mountains of the British Isles by height]], a ranking by height and prominence on the Simms classification (height over 600m, prominence over 30 m) * [[List of Marilyns in the British Isles]], a ranking by height and prominence on the Marilyn classification (any height, prominence over 150 m) * [[List of P600 mountains in the British Isles]], a ranking by height and prominence on the P600 classification (any height, prominence over 600 m)
===Isolation===
No definition of a British Isles mountain or hill uses an explicit ''quantitative'' metric of [[topographic isolation]] (e.g. distance to the next point of equal height), however, the concept of isolation is embedded in the ''qualitative'' definition of a Scottish [[Munro]], from the [[Scottish Mountaineering Club]] requirement of "sufficient separation" (instead of prominence).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.smc.org.uk/hills/hill-lists#Munros|title=Munros|publisher=[[Scottish Mountaineering Club]]|date=2018|quote=The list of distinct Scottish peaks of 3000ft (914.4m) and over, of "sufficient separation" from their neighbouring peaks. The list that was originally drawn up by Sir H.T. Munro in the Scottish Mountaineering Club Journal in 1891 was unfinished at the time of his death. Munro did not write down a precise definition of what he meant by "sufficient separation", though the character of a mountain did enter into it. Through regular use these hills have become known as the Munros.}}</ref>
===Cultural===
Mountains in [[Scotland]] are frequently referred to as "hills" no matter what their height, as reflected in names such as the ''[[Cuillin]] Hills'' and the ''[[Torridon Hills]]''.
===''Database of British and Irish Hills'' {{anchor|Database of British and Irish Hills}}===
The ''Database of British and Irish Hills'' (''DoBIH'') was created in 2001 "with the intention of providing a comprehensive, up-to-date resource for British hillwalkers".<ref name="history"/><ref name="hillsdb">{{cite web |title=Welcome |url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/index.html |website=The Database of British and Irish Hills |accessdate=10 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/blog/2016/11/birthday-celebrations-two-new-nuttalls/|title=Birthday celebrations with two new Nuttalls|publisher=[[Ordnance Survey]]|date=23 November 2016|quote=DoBIH was founded by Graham Jackson and Chris Crocker as a personal tool to help them log their own hill ascents. However, over the years DoBIH evolved into something much bigger with six editors and many hillwalkers supplying data.}}</ref> It is now maintained by a team of eight editors, and is described by the [[Long Distance Walkers Association]] as "now the most reliable online source for all Registers" (i.e. all lists of summits attained).<ref name="ldwa">{{cite web |title=Hillwakers' Register Claim Form |url=https://www.ldwa.org.uk/hillwalkers/HR_Claim_Form.pdf?ver=2 |publisher=Long Distance Walkers' Association |accessdate=10 October 2018}}</ref> The DoBIH has been used as the source by several important books on mountain classification in the British Isles, including Mark Jackson's 2010 book on HuMPS and TuMPS, titled "More Relative Hills of Britain".<ref name="Jackson"/>
DoBIH is available as a downloadable database<ref name=hillsdb /> or in an online version under the title ''Hill Bagging''.{{efn|name="dobih"|The DoBIH is licensed under a "Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/downloads.html|publisher=Database of British and Irish Hills|title=Copyright|date=3 August 2018|quote=We place no restrictions on use of the data by third parties and encourage authors of other websites and applications to do so. We just ask users to observe the terms of the Creative Commons licence}}</ref>}}<ref name="hillbagging">{{cite web |title=Hill Bagging: the online version of the Database of British and Irish Hills |url=http://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/ |website=hill-bagging.co.uk |accessdate=10 October 2018}}</ref> {{As of|August 2018}} the database included 20,859 hills, including all [[Marilyn (hill)|Marilyn]]s, [[Hump (hill)|HuMP]]s, [[Tump (hill)|TuMP]]s, [[Simm (hill)|Simm]]s, [[Dodd (hill)|Dodd]]s, [[Munro]]s and Tops, [[Corbett (hill)|Corbetts]] and Tops, [[Graham (hill)|Graham]]s and Tops, [[Donald (hill)|Donald]]s and Tops, [[List of Furths|Furths]], [[Hewitt (hill)|Hewitt]]s, [[Nuttall (hill)|Nuttall]]s, [[Buxton & Lewis]], [[Bridge (hill)|Bridge]]s, [[Murdo (hill)|Murdo]]s, [[Dewey (hill)|Dewey]]s, [[Donald Dewey (hill)|Donald Deweys]], [[Highland Five (hill)|Highland Fives]], [[List of Wainwrights|Wainwrights]], [[Birkett (hill)|Birkett]]s, [[Synge (hill)|Synges]], [[Fellranger (hill)|Fellrangers]], [[County top]]s, SIBs (Significant Islands of Britain), [[Lists of mountains in Ireland#Dillon|Dillons]], [[Arderin (hill)|Arderin]]s, [[Vandeleur-Lynam]]s, [[Myrddyn Dewey (hill)|Myrddyn Deweys]], [[Carn (hill)|Carn]]s and [[Binnion (hill)|Binnion]]s, "with subs and deletions".<ref name="dobih-downloads">{{cite web |title=Downloads |url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/downloads.html |publisher=Database of British and Irish Hills |accessdate=10 October 2018}}</ref>
Since 2012, the DoBIH has a data-sharing agreement with the Irish online database of mountains and hills, called ''[[Lists of mountains in Ireland#MountainViews Online Database|MountainViews]]'', and they hold each other's data.<ref name="history">{{cite web|url=https://www.rhb.org.uk/marhofn/marhofn316/marhofn31620.htm|title=The Database of British and Irish Hills - past, present and future|publisher=The Relative Hills of Britain (rhb.org.uk)|date=May 2016}}</ref>
==British Isles==
===P600 (the "Majors")===
(any height, prominence 600 m)
[[Image:BenNevis2005.jpg|right|thumb|[[Ben Nevis]], the highest mountain in the British Isles, which also has the greatest [[topographic prominence]].]]
The '''P600s''' are mountains in the British Isles that have a [[topographical prominence]] of at least {{convert|600|m|0|abbr=off}}, regardless of absolute height or other merits. The list was also developed by Alan Dawson in 2004 (creator of the Marilyn list), and refined in 2004 and 2006.<ref name="p600"/> Dawson initially used a 2,000 ft metric (or 610 m, the P610s), and called his list the "Majors", as it is one of the shortest of the noted lists of mountains in the British Islands, and one of the most testing requirements. The term "Major" is often used by others when listing the P600 peaks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mountainsofscotland.co.uk/Maps/mapp600.htm|title=P600 MAP|publisher=MountainsofScotland|date=2018|quote=A list of British and Irish hills with at least 600m of prominence, also known as the Major Mountains of Britain & Ireland. There are also 25 hills located in Ireland with 600m prominence. These are not displayed on the above map as OS maps do not cover Ireland.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/P600m.php|title=The P600 Peaks|publisher=HillBagging.co.uk|date=2018|quote=The map and list depict the P600m Peaks - a list of British and Irish hills with at least 600m of prominence, also known as the Major Mountains of Britain & Ireland. One of the hills, Rois-Bheinn, could be substituted by Beinn Odhar Bheag - both have a height of 882m, so you could assign to either the 774m prominence and both should be climbed.}}</ref><ref name="markt">{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/europeaklist/Home/united-kingdom|title=United Kingdom Mountains|publisher=Europeaklist|author=Mark Trengrove|quote=At the bottom of this page you will find to download and print a list of the 119 Major Summits of Britain and Ireland (i.e. those that have at least 600 metres of prominence). Also to download and print is a register of the people who have completed this [P600] list.}}</ref> In 2006, 93 P600s were identified in Great Britain: 82 in Scotland, 4 in England and 7 in Wales; together with 1 in Northern Ireland, 1 on the Isle of Man, and 24 P600s in the Republic of Ireland, which brought the total number of P600 mountains in the British Isles to 119.<ref name="p600">{{cite web|url=http://www.peaklist.org/WWlists/GB/GB600m.html|title=THE BRITISH ISLES COMBINED LIST FOR THE UNITED KINGDOM AND REPUBLIC OF IRELAND|author1=Alan Dawson|author2=Rob Woodall|author3=Jonathan de Ferranti|date=2006|quote= Previously available lists used a cutoff of 2,000 feet (609.6 meters). The 2000 foot cutoff would result in a total of 111 mountains: 90 for Great Britain, 1 for Isle of Man, and 20 for Ireland. By lowering the cutoff to 600 meters (in order to be consistent with upcoming lists for Europe), we now reach a total of 119 mountains, including 93 for Great Britain, 1 on Man, and 25 in Ireland.}}</ref> However, since 2006, Welsh peak [[Moel Siabod]]'s prominence was recalculated to 600 metres, and the list of P600s was expanded to 120.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.themountainguide.co.uk/wales/moel-siabod.htm|title=Moel Siabod|publisher=TheMountainGuide|access-date=2 December 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peakbagger.com/list.aspx?lid=4340|title=Britain and Ireland Peaks with 600 meters of Prominence|publisher=PeakBagger.com|access-date=2 December 2018}}</ref>
The British Isle P600s, contain 54 of the 282 Scottish Munros, and 10 of the 34 Non-Scottish Munros, which are also called {{slink|#Furths}}; these 64 British Isles mountains meet the designation of being above {{convert|3000|ft|0|abbr=off}} in height, and {{convert|600|m|0|abbr=off}} in prominence (e.g. "Super-Majors").
* [[List of P600 mountains in the British Isles]]
P600 is an important international mountain classification criterion, along with [[Ultra-prominent peak|Ultras]] or '''P1500''', prominence above {{convert|1500|m|0|abbr=off}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rhb.org.uk/beyond/|publisher=Relative Hills of Britian|title=Beyond Britan|quote=In Britain the main thresholds for relative height (prominence) listings are 150m, 100m and 30m. Worldwide the thresholds for prominence are larger, typically 1500m, 600m and 150m. These may be referred to as Ultras or P1500s, Majors or P600s and Marilyns or P150s.}}</ref><ref name="dobih"/> The Database of British and Irish Hills also recognises the '''P500''' mountain classification, prominence above {{convert|500|m|0|abbr=off}}.<ref name="dobih-other"/>
===Marilyns===
(any height, prominence 150 m)
[[File:Pillar and Rock.jpg|thumb|[[Pillar (mountain)|Pillar]], an English [[Marilyn (hill)|Marilyn]]]]
The '''Marilyns''' are mountains and hills in the British Isles that have a [[topographical prominence]] of at least {{convert|150|m|ft|abbr=off}}, regardless of absolute height or other merits. As at October 2018, there were 1,552 Marilyns in Great Britain:<ref name="dibh"/> 1,219 in Scotland, 175 in England, and 158 in Wales ([[Black Mountain, Wales|Black Mountain]], on the [[England-Wales border]], is counted as being in Wales). There are 454 Marilyns in Ireland (389 in the Republic of Ireland and 66 in Northern Ireland), and 5 on the [[Isle of Man]], bringing the total for the British Isles to 2,011. The list was first compiled in 1992 by Alan Dawson.<ref name="rhb"/><ref name="dobih"/> The name was coined as an ironic contrast to the designation ''Munro'', which is homophonous with [[Marilyn Monroe|''(Marilyn) Monroe'']]. The Marilyns are one of the most popular lists for peak baggers.
*[[List of Marilyns in the British Isles]] **[[List of Marilyns in Scotland]], detailed lists by sections in Scotland
=== HuMPs {{Anchor|Humps}} === (any height, prominence 100 m)
The Marilyns were expanded in 2007 by the '''HuMPs''' ('''H'''undred and '''u'''pwards '''M'''etre '''P'''rominence) which reduces the [[Topographic prominence|prominence]] requirement to {{convert|100|m|abbr=on}}. Therefore, all British Isles Marilyns are British Isles HuMPS (but not vice versa).<ref name="hb"/> The list was compiled by Mark Jackson from a number of sources and published online in 2010 in ''More Relative Hills of Britain''.<ref name="Jackson">{{cite web|last=Jackson|first=Mark|title=More Relative Hills of Britain|url=http://www.rhb.org.uk/humps/humps_1_1_0c.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012150300/http://www.rhb.org.uk/humps/humps_1_1_0c.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 October 2013|work=Relative Hills of Britain|accessdate=9 September 2011}}</ref> There are 2,986 HuMPs in the British Isles: 2,168 in Scotland, 833 in Ireland, 444 in England, 366 in Wales and 11 in the Channel Islands.<ref name="hb">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/HuMPs.php|title=The HuMPS|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=The Humps: Humps are hills of any height with a drop of 100 metres or more on all sides The name Hump stands for HUndred Metre Prominence. By definition, all Marilyns qualify as Humps (but not vice versa). A Subhump is a hill which just fails (by up to 10m) to qualify on the drop rule, i.e. drop of 90m to 99m on all sides.}}</ref>
=== Simms === (height 600 m, prominence 30 m)
A '''Simm''' is a mountain the British Isles that is over {{convert|600|m|abbr=on|0}} high and has a prominence of at least {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}}. The word comes from '''Si'''x-hundred '''M'''etre '''M'''ountain.<ref name="si"/> There are currently 2,754 recorded Simms in the British Isles, including 2,188 Scottish Simms, 192 English Simms, 149 Welsh Simms, 1 Isle of Man Simm, and 224 Irish Simms.{{efn|name="mv"}}<ref name="si">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Simms.php?ct=EWM|title=The SIMMs|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=The Simms: A Simm is a hill in England, Wales or Scotland over 600m high with a drop of at least 30 metres all-round. Simm is an acronym for Six-hundred Metre Mountain. The Irish and Isle of Man Simms are also listed on this website. A '''Sub-Simm''' is a hill which just fails (by up to 10m) to qualify on the drop rule, i.e. over 600m with 20-29m drop.}}</ref> By definition, all Simms are also [[TuMP]]s (see below) and most, if not all, are mountains, depending on whether 600 metres or 2,000 feet (610 m) (e.g. a {{slink|#Hewitts}}), is used as the criterion. The idea of the Simm was introduced by Alan Dawson in June 2010, who noted that a Simm was the "broadest credible definition of what could be objectively conceived as a mountain in Britain".<ref name="dobih">{{cite web|url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/database_notes.html#list_of_lists|title=Background to the lists|publisher=Database of British and Irish Hills|date=2 August 2018}}</ref> {{As of |October 2018}}, 6,414 people had registered themselves as having climbed all 282 Scottish Munros,<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.smc.org.uk/hills/completionists|title=Compleators|publisher=[[Scottish Mountaineering Club]]|author=Clerk of the List|date=October 2018|quote=The SMC hold a record of Munros, Corbetts, Grahams and Donalds compleators.}}</ref> over 270 people had registeted climbing all 1,552 Marilyns of Great Britain,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rhb.org.uk/marilyns/marhof.htm|title=The Marilyn Hall of Fame (Marhof)|publisher=The Relative Hills of Britain (rhb.org.uk)|date=31 December 2017}}</ref> while only 2 people had registered completion of the 2,529 Simms of Great Britain, and no one had yet declared completion of all 2,754 Simms of the British Isles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rhb.org.uk/simms/simmhof.htm|title=Simm Hall of Fame|date=6 July 2017|publisher=The Relative Hills of Britain (rhb.org.uk)|quote=A Simm is a hill in Britain that is at least 600 metres high and has a drop of at least 30 metres on all sides. Only two people are known to have climbed all 2528 Simms, but anyone with at least 2000 Simms is eligible for the Simm Hall of Fame. As this is a distant target for many baggers, the Simm Corridor is open to those who have climbed at least 1500 Simms.}}</ref>
* [[List of mountains of the British Isles by height]], a ranking by height and prominence on the Simms classification (height over 600m, prominence over 30 m)
=== TuMPs {{Anchor|Tumps}}=== (any height, prominence 30 m)
In 2010, Mark Jackson further expanded the HuMPS and compiled the '''TuMPs''' ('''T'''hirty and '''u'''wpards '''M'''etre '''P'''rominence), a list of all hills in Britain having a prominence above {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Jackson"/><ref>[http://www.rhb.org.uk/marhofn/marhofn255/Marhofn255.pdf ''Marilyn Hall of Fame News''], May 2012, p.30. Accessed on 27 Mar 2013. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130903161111/http://www.rhb.org.uk/marhofn/marhofn255/Marhofn255.pdf |date=2013-09-03 }}</ref> By definition, all Murdos, Corbett Tops, Graham Tops, Hewitts and Deweys are also TuMPs. There are 17,044 TuMPs;<ref name="tr">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Tumps.php?ct=EWM|title=The TuMPs|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=The Tumps: A Tump is a hill in Scotland, England, Wales, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands which is separated from adjacent tops by a height difference of at least 30 metres on all sides. The higher of the Tumps, including all over 500m in height, are included on other lists such as the Simms and Deweys. For the lower Tumps, the accuracy of the data on this site is not necessarily as dependable nor subject to as much scrutiny as those above 500m. For lower lying hills it can be much more difficult to identify the actual summit, so some grid references given may be more an indication of the general area of the summit. There is also a greater likelihood of encountering access problems when trying to bag lower Tumps, so please be considerate of land ownership and usage.}}</ref> approximately half of that number that did not appear in previously researched lists were researched by Mark Jackson between 2006 and 2009. Since 2012 the list has been published and maintained by the editors of The Database of British and Irish Hills.<ref name=dibh/>
==Scotland only==
===Munros=== (height 3,000 ft, other SMC criteria)
{{Main article|Munro}}
[[File:BenHopefromLochEriboll.jpg|right|thumb|[[Ben Hope]], in the [[Flow Country]], is the most northerly [[List of Munros|Munro]]]]
The '''Munros''' are mountains in Scotland over {{convert|3000|ft|sigfig=4}}. The list was originally compiled by Sir [[Hugh Munro]] in 1891, and is modified from time to time by the [[Scottish Mountaineering Club]] (SMC).<ref name="munros">{{cite book| last=Bearhop | first=D.A. | year=1997 | title=Munro's Tables | isbn=0-907521-53-3 | publisher=Scottish Mountaineering Club & Trust}}</ref> Unlike most other lists, the Munros do not depend on a rigid [[topographic prominence|prominence]] criterion for entry; instead, those that satisfy the subjective measure of being a "separate mountain" are regarded as ''Munros'', while subsidiary summits are given the status of '''Munro Tops'''. There are 282 Munros, and 227 further Munro Tops, totalling 509 summits, all of them in the [[Scottish Highlands]].
'''Real Munro''' is used to describe Munros with a prominence over {{convert|150|m}} (the Marilyn prominence threshold),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/galleries/most-beautiful-impressive-best-munros-to-climb/|title=Magnificent munros: 17 Scottish mountains to bag in your lifetime|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=13 April 2017|quote=Of the 282, 200 are said to have a summit prominence of over 150 metres and are therefore known as "real munros", but that's for another day.}}</ref> and there are 202 Real Munros in Scotland. Of the 282 Scottish Munros, 54 meet the {{convert|600|m|sigfig=4}} in prominence to be P600s.
*[[List of Munro mountains in Scotland]], list of Munros and of Munro Tops in Scotland, ranked by height and by prominence *[[List of Munros in Scotland by Section]], a breakdown of Munros into the ''Munro's Tables'' format
===Murdos=== (height 3,000 ft, prominence 30 m) [[File:Aonach beag.jpg|thumb|[[Aonach Beag]], in the [[Highlands]], one of the "mini" Murdos]]
The '''Murdos''' apply objective criteria to the [[Munro]]s and their associated tops. They comprise all the summits in Scotland over {{convert|3000|ft|sigfig=4}} with a [[topographic prominence|prominence]] of at least {{convert|30|m}}. There are currently 442 Murdos,<ref name="dibh"/> compared to 282 Munros, or 509 Munros plus Munro Tops. Alan Dawson first compiled the list in 1995.<ref name="murdos">{{cite book | title=The Murdos | last=Dawson | first=Alan | url=http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tables/murdos/ | isbn=0-9522680-3-5 | publisher=TACit Press | location=Cambuskenneth, Stirling | year=1995 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615012227/http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tables/murdos/ | archivedate=2006-06-15 | df= }}</ref>
All Murdos are also Munro Tops, but many Munro Tops fail to qualify as Murdos because of insufficient relative height. Before 1997 there were seven Murdos that were ''not'' Munro Tops, some with quite substantial relative heights.<ref>Murdos designated new Munro Tops in 1997, {{cite web |url=http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tables/murdos/sevensum.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708005137/http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tables/murdos/sevensum.html |archivedate=2007-07-08 |df= }}</ref> All seven were included in the 1997 edition of Munro's Tables, plus two non-Murdos: Little Pap on Lochnagar and Knight's Peak on Sgurr nan Gillean (deleted in September 2013 after surveying showed it to be below 3000 feet.<ref>{{cite web |title=Survey of Knight's Peak |url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/downloads.html}}</ref> Little Pap has an estimated drop of only 22 metres<ref name=dibh>{{cite web |title=Database of British and Irish Hills |url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/downloads.html |accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref> and the reason for its re-introduction to the list, following its removal in the 1981 edition of Munro's Tables,<ref>The Munros and Tops 1891–1997, http://www.hills-database.co.uk/downloads.html#munrotab</ref> is unclear. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060615012227/http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tables/murdos/ TACit Tables: The Murdos] – original published list of Murdos by region *[[List of Murdo mountains in Scotland]]
===Corbetts=== (height 2,500–3,000 ft, prominence 500 ft) [[File:Merrick galloway.JPG|thumb|[[Merrick, Galloway|Merrick]] in the [[Southern Uplands]], is both a [[List of Corbetts|Corbett]] and a [[List of Donalds|Donald]]]] The '''Corbetts''' are peaks in Scotland that are between {{convert|2500|and|3000|ft|sigfig=4}} high with a [[topographic prominence|prominence]] of at least {{convert|500|ft|sigfig=4}}.<ref>{{cite book | title=Corbett Tops and Corbetteers | last=Dawson | first=Alan |author2=Hewitt, Dave | isbn=0-9534376-1-2 | publisher=TACit Press | location=Cambuskenneth, Stirling | year=1999}}</ref> The list was compiled in the 1920s by [[John Rooke Corbett]], a Bristol-based climber and SMC member, and was published posthumously after his sister passed it to the SMC.<ref name="munros"/> {{As of | October 2018}} there are 222 Corbetts, many of them in areas of Scotland with no [[Munro]]s, include [[Moidart]], [[Ardgour]], the [[Southern Uplands]] and the islands of [[Isle of Arran|Arran]], [[Jura, Scotland|Jura]], [[Rùm]] and [[Harris, Outer Hebrides|Harris]]. * [[List of Corbett mountains in Scotland]]
A list of '''Corbett Tops''', covering every mountain in Scotland with between {{convert|2500|and|3000|ft|sigfig=4}} of height and between {{convert|100|and|500|ft|sigfig=4}} of relative height, was published by Alan Dawson in 2001. There are currently 676 of them, including the 222 Corbetts.<ref name="dibh"/>
===Grahams=== (height 2,000–2,500 ft, prominence 150 m)
[[File:Coinnich-Skye.jpg|thumb|[[Sgùrr na Coinnich]] in [[Skye]] is the Graham with the greatest prominence]]
The '''Grahams''' are mountains in Scotland between {{convert|2000|and|2499|ft|m|abbr=off}} high, with a drop of at least {{convert|150|m|ft|abbr=off}} all round.<ref>{{cite book | title=Graham Tops and Grahamists | last1=Dawson | first1=Alan |last2=Clements|first2= E.D. 'Clem'|last3= Gordon|first3=James | isbn=0-9534376-2-0 | publisher=TACit Press | location=Cambuskenneth, Stirling | year=2004}}</ref> The list of mountains fitting these criteria was first published in 1992 by Alan Dawson in ''The Relative Hills of Britain''<ref name="rhb">{{cite book| last=Dawson | first=Alan | year=1992 | title=The Relative Hills of Britain | publisher=Cicerone Press | location=Milnthorpe | isbn=1-85284-068-4}}</ref> as the Elsies (LCs, short for Lesser Corbetts). They were later named Grahams after the late Fiona Torbet (née Graham) who had compiled a similar list around the same time. Dawson continues to maintain the list, which {{as of|October 2018}} contained 219 hills distributed as follows: Highlands south of the Great Glen 87, Highlands north of the Great Glen 84, Central and Southern Scotland 23, Skye 10, Mull 7, Harris 3, Jura 2, Arran 1, Rum 1, South Uist 1. The number of Grahams was reduced from 224, following surveys in 2014 that showed Corwharn, Ben Aslak and Ladylea Hill to be below {{convert|609.6|m|ft|abbr=off}} high.<ref name="dibh"/><ref>{{cite book| year=2015 | title=The Grahams and the Donalds | isbn=978-1-907233-19-7 | publisher=Scottish Mountaineering Trust}}</ref>
* [[List of Graham mountains in Scotland]]
Dawson in 2004 published a list of '''Graham Tops''' covering every mountain in Scotland with between {{convert|2000|and|2500|ft|sigfig=4}} of height and between {{convert|30|and|150|m|sigfig=4}} of relative height. There are currently 995 of them, including the 219 Grahams.<ref name="dibh"/>
===Donalds=== (height 2,000 ft, prominence mostly over 100 ft, Scottish lowlands)
[[File:Rhinns-of-Kells-from-Craignaw.jpg|thumb|[[Corserine]], the highest point of the Rhinns of Kells range, is a Marilyn, a Donald, and a Corbett]]
The '''Donalds''' are mountains in the [[Scottish Lowlands]] over {{convert|2,000|ft|m|abbr=on}}, amongst other criteria. The list was compiled by Percy Donald in 1935 and is maintained by the SMC.<ref name="munros"/> Whether a high point is a Donald is determined by a complicated formula which also contains qualitative elements around "sufficient topographical interest".<ref name="smc"/> The formula necessitates the splitting of Donalds into '''Donald Hills''' and '''Donald Tops'''. In general, all Donald Hills have a prominence over {{convert|100|ft|1}}, but the prominence of Donald Tops can range from {{convert|16-220|ft|1}}. Donalds can be Corbetts or Grahams and the SMC state that: "Percy Donald's original Tables are seen as a complete entity, unlike the Munros, Corbetts and Grahams."<ref name="smc"/> There are 140 Donalds, comprising 89 Donald Hills and 51 Donald Tops.<ref name="smc">{{cite web|url=https://www.smc.org.uk/hills/hill-lists#Donalds|title=Donalds|publisher=[[Scottish Mountaineering Club]]|date=2018|quote=There are currently 89 Donald Hills and a further 51 Donald Tops. A complete round of The Donalds should include all 140 summits. Percy Donald's original Tables are seen as a complete entity, unlike the Munros, Corbetts and Grahams.}}</ref>
* [[List of Donald mountains in Scotland]]
Given the complexity of the Donald classification, the simpler '''New Donalds''' were introduced by Alan Dawson in his 1995 book, ''The Grahams and the New Donalds'', with an explicit prominence threshold of {{convert|30|m|1|abbr=on}};<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rhb.org.uk/tables/grahams1999.htm|title=Review: The Grahams and the New Donalds|publisher=The Relative Hills of Britain|author=Alan Dawson|date=May 1995}}</ref> there are 118 New Donalds, and while all Donald Hills are New Donalds, 22 Donald Tops are not.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Donalds.php|title=The New Donalds|publisher=HillBaggingUK|date=2018|quote=The New Donalds are an attempt to rationalize the qualifying criteria, being "hills in Central or Southern Scotland at least 2000 feet high (610m) with a drop of at least 30 metres (98 feet) all round". All New Donalds are either a Donald or a Donald Top, but some of the Donald Tops do not qualify as New Donalds.}}</ref>
* [[List of Donald mountains in Scotland|List of New Donald mountains in Scotland]]
==Outside Scotland==
===Furths=== (height 3,000 ft, any prominence) [[File:Caher, Macgillycuddy's Reeks - geograph.org.uk - 113638.jpg|thumb|[[Caher (mountain)|Caher]], an Irish Furth, and the only Furth with a prominence below 30 m{{efn|33 of the 34 SMC Furths have a prominence above {{convert|30|m|ft|0|abbr=off}}, however, [[Caher West Top]] in Ireland, has a prominence of {{convert|24|m|ft|0|abbr=off}}.}}]] '''Furths''' are mountains in Great Britain and Ireland [[wikt:furth|furth]] of (i.e. "outside") Scotland that would otherwise qualify as Munros or Munro Tops. They are sometimes referred to as the Irish, English or Welsh Munros. There are 34 furths; 15 in Wales, 13 in Ireland and 6 in England. The highest is [[Snowdon]]. Of these 34 SMC identified Furths, 33 have a prominence above {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}} (e.g. the Murdo Furths), 14 have a prominence above {{convert|150|m|abbr=on}} (e.g. the Real Munro Furths), and 10 have a prominence above {{convert|600|m|abbr=on}} (e.g. the P600 Furths).
The [[Scottish Mountaineering Club]] ("SMC") maintains the list of Furths and records claims of Munroists who go on to complete the Furths (called "Furthists").<ref>{{cite web | url=http://furthsummits.blogspot.co.uk/ | website=Final Furths and Furthists | title=Furth Completists (Furthists) List | accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref>
* [[List of Furth mountains in the British Isles]]
===Hewitts===<!-- This section is linked from [[List of Hewitts and Nuttalls in England]] --> (height 2,000 ft, prominence 30 m)
[[File:Calf Top, Middleton Fell, as seen from Castle Knott - geograph.org.uk - 1293008.jpg|thumb|[[Calf Top]] in [[Cumbria]], the smallest Hewitt which was confirmed in 2016 as almost exactly 2,000 ft.{{efn|name="ons"|The [[Ordnance Survey]] confired in 2016 that Calf Top was 6 millimetres above the 609.6 m threshold for a 2,000 ft mountain, and confirmed Calf Top as England's "last mountain".<ref name="calf"/>}}]]
The '''Hewitts''' are '''H'''ills in '''E'''ngland, '''W'''ales and '''I'''reland over '''t'''wo '''t'''housand feet (609.6 m), with a relative height of at least {{convert|30|m}}. The English<ref>{{cite book | title=The Hewitts and Marilyns of England | url=http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tables/england/ | last=Dawson | first=Alan | isbn=0-9522680-7-8 | publisher=TACit Press | location=Cambuskenneth, Stirling | year=1997 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000929190710/http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tables/england/ | archivedate=2000-09-29 | df= }}</ref> and Welsh<ref>{{cite book | title=The Hewitts and Marilyns of Wales | last=Dawson | first=Alan | url=http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tables/wales/ | isbn=0-9522680-6-X | publisher=TACit Press | location=Cambuskenneth, Stirling | year=1997 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061205211419/http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tables/wales/ | archivedate=2006-12-05 | df= }}</ref> lists were compiled and are maintained by Alan Dawson. Dawson originally called them "Sweats" in his book, being '''S'''ummits - '''W'''ales and '''E'''ngland '''A'''bove '''T'''wo thousand;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.walkhighlands.co.uk/hewitts/|title=The Hewitts: The 2000 foot summits of England and Wales|publisher=WalkingHighlands|date=2018|quote=The most satisfactory recent list in our opinion was originally compiled by Alan Dawson in his book, the Relative Hills of Britain, using a minimum reascent figure of 30 metres; this gives 317 summits in England and Wales, hills which Dawson originally named the Sweats (Summits - Wales and England Above Two thousand).}}</ref> the Irish<ref>{{cite book | title=The Hewitts and Marilyns of Ireland | last=Clements | first=E.D. 'Clem' | isbn=0-9522680-8-6 | publisher=TACit Press | location=Cambuskenneth, Stirling | year=1998}}</ref> list is by Clem Clements. The list addresses one of the criticisms of the Nuttalls by requiring hills to have a relative height of {{convert|30|m}}, thus excluding the 125 least prominent Nuttalls from the list.
{{As of | October 2018}}, the DoBIH listed 524 Hewitts, 209 in Ireland,{{efn|name="mv"|{{As of | October 2018}}, the Irish [[MountainViews Online Database]], list the prominence of Knockbrinnea (W) as 29m, and Carrignabinnia as 27 m, and thus they do not qualify as Irish Arderins, which means that MountainViews does not classify these two peaks as Hewitts or Simms; the total number of Irish Arderins over 2,000 ft is thus 207. The [[DoBIH]] however uses the ''Harvey Tables'' which list the prominence for both at 30 m, and thus the DoBIH class them as Irish Hewitts and Simms, giving 209 Irish Hewitts and 224 Irish Simms on the DoBIH tables.}} 180 in England and 135 in Wales. Since their publication in 1997, Birks Fell in England and Mynydd Graig Goch have been added and Black Mountain deemed to be in Wales only. There is no Scottish equivalent of a Hewitt (e.g. Murdos meet the criteria for mountains over 3,000 ft, but Corbetts and Grahams have higher prominence thresholds). Hewitts are a sub-class of the newer 2010 British Isles classification, the {{slink|#Simms}}, or "metric Hewitt", with a {{convert|600|m|1}} height threshold, and a {{convert|30|m|1}} prominence threshold. Simms have replaced Hewitts, however, Dawson still maintains a list of Hewitts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/database_notes.html|title=Database Notes: Hewitts|publisher=[[Database of British and Irish Hills]]|author=Chris Crocker|quote=In June 2010 Dawson created the Simms (Six-hundred Metre Mountains; originally called Sims) by combining the Murdos, Corbett Tops, Graham Tops and Hewitts and lowering the height threshold to 600m. [...] Hewitts are Hills in England, Wales and Ireland at least 2000 feet high with a drop of at least 30 metres on all sides. Although subsumed into the Simms, the list has been retained by its author.}}</ref>
*[[List of Hewitt mountains in England, Wales and Ireland]]
===Nuttalls=== (height 2,000 ft, prominence 15 m) [[File:Skiddaw and Little Man.JPG|thumb|[[Skiddaw]], an English Nuttall]] The '''Nuttalls''' are mountains in England and Wales only (e.g. not Ireland) over {{convert|2000|ft|m|0}} with a relative height of at least {{convert|15|m}}. There were 444 Nuttalls in the original list (254 in England and 190 in Wales), compiled by [http://www.nuttalls.com/ John and Anne Nuttall] and published in 1989-90 in two volumes, ''The Mountains of England & Wales''.<ref name="Nuttall 2008"/><ref> {{cite book | last=Nuttall | first=John & Anne | title=The Mountains of England & Wales – Volume 1: Wales | edition= 3rd | year=2009 | publisher=Cicerone | location=Milnthorpe, Cumbria | isbn=1-85284-304-7}} </ref> After updates<ref name="nuttall-changes">{{cite web |title=Changes |url=http://www.nuttalls.com/mountains/2000.htm |website=The Mountains of England and Wales |publisher=John and Anne Nuttall |accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref> the total reached 446 in August 2018 with the inclusion of [[Miller Moss]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Lake District hill Miller Moss reclassified as a mountain |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-cumbria-45141891 |accessdate=10 August 2018 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=10 August 2018}}</ref>
By including high points that rise by as little as {{convert|15|m}} above their surroundings, the list of Nuttalls is sometimes criticised for including too many insignificant minor tops. The Hewitts (see above) are one attempt to avoid this. Some Nuttalls would therefore not be considered peaks or mountains under UIAA definitions.<ref name="uiaa"/>
With the exception of Pillar Rock, a rocky outcrop on [[Pillar (Lake District)|Pillar]] in the [[Lake District]], the peaks of all of the Nuttalls can be reached without resort to [[climbing|rock climbing]]. {{As of|October 2018}}, 302 people are known to have completed the list, though this includes some who did not climb Pillar Rock, which the authors permit. They have also announced that Tinside Rigg and Long Fell (added to the list in 2016) need not be climbed as they are in a restricted area of [[Warcop Training Area|Warcop Artillery Range]].<ref name="completers">{{cite web |title=Completers |url=http://www.nuttalls.com/mountains/completers.shtml |website=The Mountains of England and Wales |publisher=John and Anne Nuttall |accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref>
* [[List of Nuttall mountains in England and Wales]]
==England only==
===Wainwrights=== (subjective listing, Lake District NP)
The '''Wainwrights''' are mountains or hills (locally known as ''[[fells]]'') in the English [[Lake District National Park]] that have a chapter in one of [[Alfred Wainwright]]'s ''[[Pictorial Guides to the Lakeland Fells]]''. There are 214 Wainwrights in the seven guides. There are no qualifications for inclusion other than Wainwright's choice. The lowest is [[Castle Crag]] in Borrowdale, at {{convert|951|ft|m}}. A further 116 summits were included in the supplementary guide, ''[[The Outlying Fells of Lakeland]]'', and are known as the '''Wainwright Outlying Fells'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Wainwrights.php|title=Wainwrights and Wainwright Outlying Fells|publisher=HillBaggingUK|date=2018|quote=The Wainwrights: The Wainwrights are a list of hills appearing in the seven volumes of Alfred Wainwright's Pictorial Guides to the Lakeland Fells; the list is subjective - some of the hills are not summits at all - just prominent points at the end of a ridge or spur from a higher mountain.<br>The [Wainwright] Outlying Fells: Wainwright produced an additional volume entitled The Outlying Fells of Lakelands.}}</ref>
* [[List of Wainwrights in the Lake District]], includes Wainwrights and Wainwright Outlying Fells * [[The Outlying Fells of Lakeland]], from the book Wainwright with additional detail on Wainwright Outlying Fells
===Birketts=== (height 1,000 ft, Lake District NP)
[[File:Pillar Rock from Robinson's Cairn.jpg|thumb|[[Pillar (Lake District)#Pillar Rock|Pillar Rock]] in the [[Lake District National Park]] is the only Birkett that requires ropes to climb.<ref name="pillar">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/PillarRock.htm|title=Pillar Rock|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=Pillar Rock, qualifying as a separate summit to [[Pillar (Lake District)]] itself in the Nuttalls and other lists [the Birketts], is the bane of summit baggers everywhere. Wainwright says that, to walkers "Pillar Rock is positively out of bounds. Don't even try to get a foothold on it". It's graded as a "moderate" rock climb.}}</ref>]]
The '''Birketts''' are all the fell tops over {{convert|1000|ft|1}} within the boundaries of the [[Lake District National Park]]. Height and location, but not prominence, are the criteria. The list was devised by [[Bill Birkett]] as the basis for his 1994 book ''Complete Lakeland Fells''.<ref>Bill Birkett, ''Complete Lakeland Fells'', London: HarperCollins / Premier Books (1994), {{ISBN|0583-32209-3}}</ref> There are 541 of these tops, and they include 209 of the 214 Wainwrights, and 59 of the 116 Wainwright Outlying Fells.<ref name="boh">{{cite web|url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/|title=Birketts|publisher=[[Database of British and Irish Hills]]|date=2018}}</ref> The 5 Wainwrights that are not Birketts are: [[Armboth Fell]], [[Baystones]], [[Castle Crag]] (which, at {{convert|951|ft|m}}, is Wainwright's only sub-1,000 ft summit), [[Graystones]] and [[Mungrisdale Common]]. Birketts are listed in the {{slink|#Database of British and Irish Hills}}.<ref name=dibh/>
* [[List of Birketts in the Lake District]]
==Ireland only== {{see also|Lists of mountains in Ireland}}
[[File:Doolough - MweelRea.JPG|thumb|upright=1.6|[[Mweelrea]] from [[Doo Lough (Mayo)|Doo Lough]] in [[Connemara]]. Mweelrea is the highest Provincial Top in [[Connaught]], the highest County Top in [[County Mayo|Mayo]], the 5th highest Irish P600 mountain, the 14th highest Irish Marilyn mountain, the 16th highest Irish MountainViews mountain, the 26th highest Irish Arderin/Hewitt mountain, and the 34th highest Irish Vandeleur-Lynam/Nuttall mountain. It is not a Furth (or Irish Munro), and therefore not a Real Munro.]]
===Vandeleur-Lynams===
(height 600 m, prominence 15 m)
The '''Vandeleur-Lynam''' is the Irish equivalent of a Nuttall, except that the definition is fully metric, with a height requirement of {{convert|600|m|0}}, and prominence requirement of {{convert|15|m|0}}.<ref name="collins">Mountainviews, (2013), "A Guide to Ireland's Mountain Summits: The Vandeleur-Lynams & the Arderins", Collins Books, Cork, {{ISBN|978-1-84889-164-7}}</ref> As with the Nuttalls, Vandeleur-Lynams do not meet the UIAA requirements for a "peak" or "mountain".<ref name="uiaa"/> In 1952, Irish climber Joss Lynam produced a list of 2,000 ft Irish summits with 50 ft drop with assistance from Rev CRP Vandeleur. Lynam updated a version of this list and published it in a reprint of "Mountaineering in Ireland" by Claude Wall, printed in 1976. The metricised equivalent was first published in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/VandeleurLynams.php?ct=I|title=The Vandeleur-Lynams|publisher=HillBagging.co.uk}}</ref> There are 273 Vandeleur-Lynams in Ireland.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mountainviews.ie/lists/vandeleur-lynam/?PHPSESSID=6lpes93lcdlq890dprmqqu4dn6|title=Vandeleur-Lynams: Irish mountains of 600+m with a prominence of 15m|publisher=MountainViews.ie|date=October 2018}}</ref>
* [[Lists of mountains in Ireland#List of 273 Irish Vandeleur-Lynams|List of Vandeleur-Lynams in Ireland]]
===Arderins===
(height 500 m, prominence 30 m)
[[File:The Fanning Pass - geograph.org.uk - 586980.jpg|thumb|The summit of [[Arderin]] (527 m) mountain in Ireland, the 344th highest ''Arderin'' in Ireland, and the Irish County Top for both [[Laois]] and [[Offaly]] counties]]
The '''Arderins''' are mountains in Ireland above {{convert|500|m|0|abbr=on}}, with a prominence over {{convert|30|m|0|abbr=on}}. The list was drawn up in 2002 by the Irish ''MountainViews'' publisher Simon Stewart from an early listing of the Myrddyn Deweys with hills from the Vandeleur-Lynams which meet the higher prominence criterion. The name, Arderins, was used in 2009, comes from the 527 m hill, [[Arderin]], which is the County Top for [[County Laois]] and [[County Offaly]] in Ireland, and translates as "Height of Ireland".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Arderins.php|title=The Arderins|publisher=HillBagging.co.uk}}</ref> The Arderins were published in the 2013 book, "A Guide to Ireland's Mountain Summits: The Vandeleur-Lynams & the Arderins".<ref name="collins"/> According to the MountainViews Online Database, Ireland has 407 Arderins,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mountainviews.ie/lists/arderin/|title=Arderins: Irish mountains of 500+m with a prominence of 30m|publisher=MountainViews.ie|date=October 2018}}</ref> of which 207 are over 2,000 ft and classed as Hewitts, and the 222 are over 600 m and classed as Simms.{{efn|name="mv"}}
* [[Lists of mountains in Ireland#List of 407 Irish Arderins|List of Arderins in Ireland]]
In addition, Mountainviews uses the term '''Arderin Begs''' for the additional class of peaks over {{convert|500|m|0|abbr=on}} in height, and with a prominence between {{convert|15-30|m|0|abbr=on}}. In 2018, Ireland had 124 Arderin Begs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mountainviews.ie/lists/arderinall/|title=Arderins + Arderin Begs: Irish mountains of 500+m with a prominence of 15+m|publisher=MountainViews|author=Simon Stewart|date=2018|quote=Listing selection: All summits (531) in list Arderins + Arderin Begs}}</ref>
===MountainViews===
(height 500 m, prominence 100 m)
In 2013, Simon Stewart, publisher of Irish mountain database ''[[List of mountains in Ireland#MountainViews Online Database|MountainViews Online Database]]'', published: "A Guide to Ireland's Mountain Summits: The Vandeleur-Lynams & the Arderins".<ref name="collins"/> In the book, Stewart proposed a new classification of an Irish mountain, being one with a height above {{convert|500|m|0|abbr=on}}, and a prominence over {{convert|100|m|0|abbr=on}}. Stewart identified 222 Irish peaks as meeting his new classification. MountainViews used this definition to create the list of ''100 Highest Mountains in Ireland'',<ref name="top">{{cite web|url=https://mountainviews.ie/credits/|title=Credits and Acknowledgements: Lists of the summits, islands and coastal features for Ireland.|publisher=Mountainview.ie|date=2018|quote=The "Hundred Highest" list includes summits with a prominence at a minimum of 100 m, and has been introduced to give a height based list, not too long, with a spread of locations for Ireland.}}</ref> which has also become popular to use in Ireland.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://outsider.ie/ireland/highest-mountains-ireland/|title=10 of the Highest Mountains to Climb in Ireland|quote=We’ve compiled a list of the 10 highest mountains in Ireland for you to get your teeth into.|publisher=Outsider.ie|date=2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://outsider.ie/ireland/irish-mountains/|title=The Complete Guide to Exploring Ireland's Mountains|publisher=Outsider.ie|date=2018|quote=Top 50 highest peaks in Ireland: MountainViews.ie}}</ref>
* [[Lists of mountains in Ireland#List of 100 Highest Irish Mountains|List of ''100 Highest Irish Mountains'']]
===Carns {{anchor|Carn}}===
(height 400m-499.9m, prominence 30m)
MountainViews and Database of British and Irish Hills recognise a list of 337 summits as '''Carns''', having height above {{convert|100|m|0|abbr=on}} and below {{convert|400|m|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="mv-carns">{{cite web |title=Carns |url=https://mountainviews.ie/lists/carn/?inForm=Y|publisher=MountainViews |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref><ref name="dbih-background">{{cite web |title=Background to the lists |url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/database_notes.html#history |publisher=Database of British and Irish Hills |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
===Binnions {{Anchor|Binnion}}===
(height below 400m, prominence 100m)
MountainViews and Database of British and Irish Hills recognise a list of 484 summits as '''Binnions''', having prominence at least {{convert|100|m|0|abbr=on}} and height below {{convert|400|m|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="mv-binnions">{{cite web |title=Binnions |url=https://mountainviews.ie/lists/binnion/?inForm=Y |publisher=MountainViews |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref><ref name="dbih-background" /> Binnion Hill is a summit of 250m in County Donegal, site of the [[Battle of Binnion Hill]] and possibly the source of the name.<ref name="binnion-hill">{{cite web |title=Binnion |url=https://mountainviews.ie/summit/1003/ |publisher=MountainViews |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
==County tops {{anchor|County tops}}==
Climbing in the highest point of each county is a popular form of [[peak bagging]], dating back to the 1920s when [[John Rooke Corbett]] was attempting to visit all British '''County Tops'''.
* [[List of counties of England and Wales in 1964 by highest point]] * [[List of English counties by highest point]] * [[List of Welsh principal areas by highest point]] * [[List of Scottish counties by highest point]] * [[List of Scottish council areas by highest point]] * [[List of Irish counties by highest point]]
== Other active lists ==
===Deweys{{anchor|Deweys}}=== (height 500m to <2,000ft, prominence 30 m)
The '''Deweys''' and related categories extend the Hewitts of England, Wales and Ireland to 500 metres, and include summits in Scotland, where there are no Hewitts.
* The '''Deweys''' are peaks in England, Wales and the Isle and Man between 500 metres and {{convert|2,000|ft|1|abbr=off}} in height, with a [[topographic prominence|prominence]] above {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=off}}, which were listed by Michael Dewey in 1995.<ref>{{cite book | last=Dewey | first=Michael | year=1995 | title=Mountain Tables: Tables of the mountain and hill summits of England and Wales| publisher=Constable & Co Ltd | isbn=0-09-474520-X}}</ref> Deweys extend the England and Wales Hewitts below 2,000 feet, but above 500 metres. There are 426 Deweys identified: 241 in Wales, 180 in England, and 5 in Manx.<ref name="dw">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Deweys.php?ct=EWM|title=The Deweys|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=The Deweys: A Dewey is "a mountain or hill in England, Wales or the Isle of Man, that exceeds 500 metres in height, but is below 610 metres (2000ft) in altitude; it must be separated from adjacent tops by a height difference of at least 30 metres on all sides". The definition is similar to the Hewitts and Simms, except that Hewitts must be above 2000ft, and Simms above 600m. The Deweys are named after the list's compiler, Michael Dewey, the list appearing as one of the chapters in his book, Mountain Tables.}}</ref>
* The '''Donald Deweys''' are peaks in the Scottish lowlands (e.g. like the Donald classification), between 500 metres and {{convert|2,000|ft|1|abbr=off}} in height, with a [[topographic prominence|prominence]] above {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=off}}, which were listed by David Purchase in 2001.<ref name="dondew"/> Donald Deweys are the Scottish lowland equivalent of Deweys. There are 248 Donald Deweys.<ref name="dondew">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/HighlandFives.php?ct=S|title=The Donald Deweys|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=A Donald Dewey is a hill in the Scottish Lowlands between 500m and 609m high with a drop of at least 30m on all sides. [...] There are 248 Donald Deweys. [...] The Deweys were extended to Ireland (the Myrddyn Deweys) by Michael Dewey and Myrddyn Phillips in 2000, and to the Scottish Lowlands (Donald Deweys) by David Purchase in 2001.}}</ref>
* The '''Highland Fives''' are peaks in the Scottish highlands, between 500 metres and {{convert|2,000|ft|1|abbr=off}} in height, with a [[topographic prominence|prominence]] above {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=off}}, which were listed by Rob Woodhall in 2003.<ref name="highgive"/> Highland Fives are the Scottish highland equivalent of Deweys. There are 774 Highland Fives.<ref name="highgive">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/HighlandFives.php?ct=S|title=Highland Fives|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=A Highland Five is a hill in the Scottish Highlands between 500m and 609m high with a drop of at least 30m on all sides. [...] There are 774 Highland Fives. [...] Hitherto, 500m hills in the Scottish Highlands have not had a separate identity, but a complete listing of Scottish 500m hills was compiled by Rob Woodall using data from Tony Payne, Clem Clements, John Kirk and others and uploaded to the rhb group (2003, revised 2006).}}</ref>
* The '''Myrddyn Deweys''' are peaks in Ireland, between 500 metres and {{convert|2,000|ft|1|abbr=off}} in height, with a [[topographic prominence|prominence]] above {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=off}}, which were listed by Michael Dewey and Myrddyn Phillips in 2000.<ref name="myrddyn"/> Myrddyn Deweys are the Irish equivalent of Deweys. There are 200 Myrddyn Deweys.<ref name="myrddyn">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/MyrddynDeweys.php?ct=I|title=Myrddyn Deweys|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=The Myrddyn Deweys are hills in Ireland with a height between 500-609m and a prominence of 30m. The list was researched by Michael Dewey and Myrddyn Phillips and was made freely available to the Mountaineering Council of Ireland in 2000. In 2011 the data was re-examined against the latest mapping. [...] There are 200 Myrddyn Deweys.}}</ref>
=== Dodds === (height 500 to <600m, prominence 30 m)
The '''Dodds''' is a list of hills in the England, Wales, and Scotland between {{convert|500-600|m|ft|abbr=off}} in height, with a [[topographic prominence|prominence]] above {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=off}}. The criteria for Dodds are designed to include Simms below 600 metres, but above 500 metres. In 2015, the ''Relative Hill of Britain'' site identified 1,339 Dodds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhb.org.uk/dodds/|title=Dodds|publisher=The Relative Hills of Britian|quote=A Dodd is a hill in Britain at least 500m high and under 600m that has a drop (relative height) of 30 metres or more on all sides. There were 1340 Dodds at the end of 2015.|author=}}</ref> The name comes from '''DO'''nald '''D'''eweys, '''D'''eweys and '''S'''cotland.<ref name="dd">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Dodds.php?ct=EWM|title=The Dodds|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=A Dodd is a hill in England, Wales or Scotland between 500m and 599m high with a drop of at least 30 metres all round. The name Dodds was originally derived from DOnald Deweys, Deweys and Scotland. A Sub-Dodd, is a hill which just fails (by up to 10m) to qualify on the drop rule, i.e. between 500m and 599m with 20-29m drop.}}</ref>
=== Hardys === (hill range summits)
A '''[[Hardy (hill)|Hardy]]''' is the highest point of a UK hill range, a UK island over {{convert|1,000|acre|ha|abbr=off}} or 4.05 km²) or a UK top-tier administrative area (counties and unitary authorities). There are now 347 Hardys with the recent addition (up to July 2016) of 5 low lying English coastal estuary islands: 61 hill ranges, 96 islands and 190 administrative areas. 183 are in England, 31 in Wales, 107 in Scotland and 26 in Northern Ireland. The list was first compiled in the 1990s by Ian Hardy.<ref>Hardy, Ian, MVO (2010). ''The Hardys – The UK's High Points'' (3rd Edition). Potters Bar, Hertfordshire: Ian Hardy. {{ISBN|978 0 9565533 3 1}} (internet version, http://www.thehardys.org/), {{ISBN|978 0 9565533 5 5}} (DVD version).</ref><ref>[http://www.haroldstreet.org.uk/waypoints/download/?list=hardys ''Hardys Hill List and GPS Waypoints''] at www.haroldstreet.org.uk. Retrieved 6 Jan 2017.</ref>
== Non-active lists == ===Bridges=== The Database of British and Irish Hills recognises as '''Bridges''' the 407 summits in George Bridge's ''Mountains of England and Wales: Tables of the 2000ft Summits'' (1973, West Col Productions),<ref name=dbih-background /> and a list is available on the HillBagging site.<ref name="hb-bridges">{{cite web |title=List of Bridges |url=http://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/search.php?qu=Bg&ty=Bg |publisher=HillBagging |accessdate=16 October 2018}} ''Not titled, but linked from "Bridges" in HillBagging's [http://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/OtherLists.php "Other lists" page]''</ref> While all Bridges are over 2,000 ft, there is no prominence threshold, however the list is similar to the 446 Nuttals.<ref name="dobih-other"/>
=== Buxton & Lewis === The Database of British and Irish Hills recognises as '''Buxton & Lewis''' the 422 summits in the book by Chris Buxton and Gwyn Lewis, ''Mountain Summits of England and Wales'' (1986, {{ISBN|9780951172308}}, Red Dial Publications),<ref name=dbih-background /> and a list is available on the HillBagging site.<ref name="hb-buxton">{{cite web |title=List of Buxton-Lewis summmits |url=http://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/search.php?qu=BL&ty=BL |publisher=HillBagging |accessdate=16 October 2018}} ''Not titled, but linked from "Buxton-Lewis" in HillBagging's [http://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/OtherLists.php "Other lists" page]''</ref> While all Buxton & Lewis summits are over 2,000 ft, there is no prominence threshold, however the list is similar to the 446 Nuttals.<ref name="dobih-other"/>
===Fellrangers=== The Database of British and Irish Hills recognises as '''Fellrangers''' the 227 Lake District summits in Mark Richard's ''Fellranger'' series of eight guidebooks (originally published Harper Collins startring with ''Central Fells'' {{ISBN|9780007113651}}; reprinted by Cicerone; 2013 boxed set {{ISBN|978-1852847487}}),<ref name=dbih-background /> and a list is available on the HillBagging site.<ref name=fellrangers>{{cite web |title=The Fellrangers |url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Fellrangers.php |publisher=HillBagging |accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref> There is no height or prominence threshold.<ref name="dobih-other">{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/OtherLists.php|title=Other Lists|publisher=HillBagging|accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref>
===Synges=== The Database of British and Irish Hills recognises as '''Synges''' the 647 Lake District summits in Timothy Synge's ''The Lakeland Summits: Survey of the Fells of the Lake District National Park'' (1995, Sigma: {{ISBN| 978-1850584469}}),<ref name=dbih-background /> and a list is available on the HillBagging site.<ref name=synges>{{cite web |title=The Synges |url=http://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Synges.php|publisher=HillBagging |accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref> There is no height or prominence threshold.<ref name="dobih-other"/>
==Regional lists==
The following are lists of hills for a given region in the British Isles:
England: *[[List of hills of Cornwall]] *[[List of hills of Dorset]] *[[List of hills of Gloucestershire]] *[[List of hills of Hampshire]] *[[List of hills of Wiltshire]] *[[List of hills in the Peak District]]

'''Newtown''', is a district in the [[Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago]]. Over the years Newtown has evolved into a fairly well developed business area with large residences being converted into business places or being torn down with the intention to build a more business like location.
==Churches within the Newtown area: St. Patrick's R.C. Church and St. Crispin's Anglican Church==
One of the older buildings which has retained most of its historical look is the St. Patrick's R.C. Church.<ref>http://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/St-Patricks-Church-still-needs-help-256102541.html</ref> In 2014, renovations to the roof and other areas were completed with funds raised by the parishioners over a number of years. This church boasts of several stained glass windows and is styled in a similar manner to the St. Crispin's Anglican Church which is located a few streets away in close proximity to the Siegert Square. Both churches have antique baptismal fonts at the back of the church.
==Schools within the Newtown area==
Newtown is one of the areas which had at least one primary school for boys and one for girls, which is the Newtown Boys and Newtown Girls. Known for success in academics and Music Festival competitions, these schools are located on either side of the St. Patrick's R.C. Church with access from Maraval Road.
There are also private secondary schools and Government run schools located in close proximity to Maraval Road and Tragarete Road, such as Wood Brook Secondary School and St. Cecelia's Private Secondary School.
Over the years a branch of a tertiary educational institute, SBCS, has offered its services from two locations on Picton Street.<ref>http://www.sbcs.edu.tt/campuses/port-of-spain-campus/</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Geography of Port of Spain]]
